title: Monday, 2nd September 2019

BE11:18am

PMI and Brexit

BE11:18am

(@tangledodyssey: pretty much, yes.)

11:19 am
BE11:20am

HSBC can talk us through the former. Dante himself would struggle to talk us through the latter.

BE11:20am

The UK's manufacturing PMI fell to 47.4 in August (from 48.0 in July) - a seven year low.
Consensus had been expecting a small rise to 48.4.
The picture was gloomy across the board: the new orders index fell by 2.5 points to a seven-year
low. Firms cited "weaker domestic and global economic conditions, low market confidence, Brexit
concerns, business uncertainty and a slowdown in client spending".
New export orders also fell at their fastest pace in seven years, with some firms reporting that their
EU-based clients have started to reroute supply chains away from the UK ahead of its scheduled
departure from the EU on 31 October.
Employment growth was negative, as it has been for eight of the last eleven months.
There is no indication yet of companies rebuilding stockpiles: both stocks of purchases and
quantity of purchases continue to fall back.

BE11:20am

Input and output price inflation both ticked higher in August. Of firms which saw costs rise, 80%
linked this to the fall in sterling. However, both indices look relatively contained so far by recent
standards.

tangledodyssey Poor Dante, much maligned!
11:20 am
BE11:21am

Implications
This is the worst of both worlds for the UK's manufacturers: output is falling, and the fall in the
currency is pushing prices up - but not giving the UK a boost in export orders.
Of course, we can't just blame Brexit for the UK's manufacturing woes. The German
manufacturing PMI was even worse in August, dropping to 43.5. Clearly, there are global factors
affecting manufacturing worldwide. In this sense, with a service sector accounting for 80% of
output, the UK is relatively well placed.
But at the same time, Brexit is not helping in an already difficult climate. If the new PM Boris
Johnson's goal was to make credible his intention to leave "with or without a deal", it appears he
has been successful: the latest Betfair odds suggest a 38% chance of a 'no deal' Brexit, and today's
PMI survey suggests that EU companies are taking more concrete actions to re-route supply chains
away from the UK, while domestic manufacturers are becoming more pessimistic.

Maverick Morning all, good to have you back Bryce
BE11:22am

And Caz.

BE11:22am

Taken at face value, we read the PMI as signalling an annualised contraction in manufacturing output of close to 3%. This is a signal about the underlying, with the official data also being buffeted by idiosyncratic moves related to the precise timing of the Brexit deadline. For this reason IP was strong in 1Q and then collapsed on 2Q. Monday’s July monthly GDP release will give a sense of how these idiosyncrasies are playing out into 3Q and will steer our forecast for the current quarter. But there is no doubt that the trend within the sector has weakened significantly in recent months and has yet to show a clear stabilisation. We will review our near-term growth forecast after this Wednesday’s services PMI.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

BE11:24am

Yep, doesn't look great. But I guess post October 31 we'll have all the manufacturing we need.

Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:25am

Meanwhile, here comes those traitors at Deutsche Bank to say short sterling.

Richard Morning all
11:25 am
BE11:26am

With Parliament set to return tomorrow, the window for MPs to force anti no-deal legislation through both Houses is very narrow. The reports over the weekend that any Tory MP who votes against the whip will face deselection increases at the margin the risk that the legislation fails at the first hurdle. However, even if the bill goes through the Commons and Lords by the end of the weekend, the risk is that PM Johnson either ignores the legislation or calls a snap election and runs on a no-deal platform. With the EU stance on the backstop holding firm for now, the risks in the very near term seem asymmetrically to the downside for sterling.
While the futures' market showed a marginal increase in GBP shorts last week, our own option flow monitor points to more buying of upside in recent weeks (figure 1), potentially leaving the pound more vulnerable to negative news than a few weeks ago. Our recent analysis shows that GBP/JPY has on average proven the most sensitive cross to UK political news. (figure 2)

marktime Didn't Soros short the pound once already?

11:28 am
BE11:28am

With Boris Johnson last week having shortened the window for action by deciding to prorogue Parliament, this week has thus become crucial for those wishing to thwart a no deal Brexit. Battle lines are drawn.
Although the full details are being kept under wraps, it appears that an alliance of Remainer MPs will attempt to legislate for the PM to request another extension to Article 50. The process begins tomorrow with an application for an emergency debate (Standing Order 24). While this process does not normally involve a binding vote, it appears that the alliance believes Speaker John Bercow will break with convention and allow it on this occasion. This could then give Parliament the right to set the business on Wednesday, thus paving the way for a binding vote on this issue possibly the next day. If successful, the legislation would make its way to the House of Lords. According to reports, all of this has to be done prior to next Monday if it is to pass into law and not simply fall by the wayside when prorogation begins next week.
Boris Johnson’s government has already come out fighting, with pledges to deselect those Tories who defy the whip, attempt to “filibuster” the legislation in the House of Lords or simply ignore it if it is passed.
They say that a week is a long time in politics, but with the amount of action likely to take place this week in London, including the possibility that a general election will be called, it may feel like an eternity.

cracklenpop Given the scale of sterling's depreciation since the EU referendum, this must be the weakest post-devaluation ecomomic 'recovery' in living memory.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Diabetes thing, also potentially useful for heart disease it turns out.

BE11:34am

We knew headline results already. What we didn't know is a 26% survival rate on a P of less than 0.0001 if you like your P values.

BE11:35am

Which adds a billlion, maybe billion and a half, to Farxiga revenue in the outer years.

Shinshin @marktime The Furgonocchanetaixisia Weekly Observer
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Possibly. Assuming the data stand up with the FDA. Though you also have a patent expiry in 2025 to confuse future value.

BE11:38am

Slide pack is here if you want it: https://www.astraz...am/az/PDF/2019/AZN ESC DAPA-HF 2019.pdf

BE11:39am

Gah, link broken. Top of the page here: https://www.astraz...presentations.html

11:39 am
BE11:39am

And Caz to explain what you're looking at:

BE11:39am

The detailed data presentation was very strong, with a 26% benefit on the primary endpoint of worsening
heart failure or cardiovascular death, with the result also being highly statistically significant (HR 0.74 was
p=0.00001), consistent with comments in the previous headline release that there was a clinically meaningful
and substantial efficacy benefit. We see the efficacy profile as impressive, being on top of SOC that could
include diuretics, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, Entresto, Beta blockers, MRA, ICDs etc. We note Entresto had an HR
of 0.80, vs. enalapril in the PARADIGM heart failure study in reduced ejection fraction patients.
Efficacy was strong across components of the primary, and consistent across different patient subgroups.

BE11:39am

Efficacy was strong for both components of the primary; worsening HF HR 0.70 (p=0.00003) and CV death HR
0.82 (p=0.029). Benefits were also consistent across all subgroups, including whether patients had diabetes at
baseline (HR 0.75 with Diabetes, HR 0.73 without baseline Diabetes). Strong efficacy was also seen irrespective
of whether patients were on Entresto (HR 0.75 on Entresto, 0.74 not on Entresto).

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Side effects / tolerability also looked acceptable, with the Farxiga arm showing lower incidence of worsening
renal function [HR 0.71, p=0.17, 1.2% on Farxiga, 1.6% on placebo]. Only 4.7% of Farxiga patients
discontinued therapy, vs. 4.9% of placebo patients.

BE11:40am

Based on the strong data presentation yesterday, we believe Astra shares could see a 1-2 pp of further
outperformance today, as Farxiga expectations are raised on the back of the strong data. Our model still
includes just $0.9bn peak potential, which we then risk-adjust at 60% POS, worth 0.7% of our NPV at present,
removal of the risk-adjustment potentially adding 0.6% to our NPV. Our modelling notes the c.15% payaway to
BMY, and the 2025 US patent expiry. Based on this strong data presented yesterday, if reduced ejection fraction
heart failure could be a $4bn indication, (as per NOVN for Entresto), and with Astra potentially splitting the
SGLT-2 angle with Jardiance (data 2020, also likely to work), this could be a $2bn opportunity for Astra, which
could be worth c.3% / c.£1.50 per Astra share.

BE11:42am

And Goldman.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

We view the magnitude of benefit offered by Farxiga in reducing the composite of CV death or worsening of heart failure in patients with HFrEF as a minor positive for AZN. We note that Lilly’s Jardiance is also being evaluated in heart failure patients with HFrEF (EMPEROR-Reduced study), with topline results expected in 2H20 (as per clinicaltrials.gov).
We forecast 2019 sales of c.US$1.6bn for Farxiga (c.7% of Group sales).

BE11:43am

So far, consensus has included 2024 sales of just under USD2.5bn for
Forxiga. We think that having seen this data, at a minimum, consensus
2024 estimates should rise by USD1bn, and potentially more, to at least
USD3.5bn sales by 2024. That could mean at least a further 5% upside to
mid-term (2024) EPS, and at least 2-3% upside to Astra’s value. The true
valuation upside is held back by: 1) Forxiga’s initial patent expiring only
around 2025; and 2) Lilly’s Jardiance has a similar study reading out mid-
2020. An obvious HF precedent is Novartis’s Entresto, which in a similar
HF population, looks set to reach USD4bn peak sales, despite its slow
initial start. We stress that Farxiga showed exactly the same benefit when
it was added on top of Entresto, so it will not really be a direct competitor:
optimal therapy would be both. However, some concern over Entresto
losing new HF patients is inevitable: we look at this in detail from page 2.
We will update our model and TP (based on NPV SOP, cost of equity 9%) in
due course: Astra’s very positive H2 2019 readouts continue.

Smiths announced back in March that it is planning to separate its medical unit in 1H20 into a separate UK lised entity, but they have said they'd be open to offers during the listing process. We believe a clean exit from Medical would be preferable. The question mark will be around valuation, with Smiths already failing to agree a price with ICU Medical last year.
